articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Callum Hart)
articles.description: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elad Shechter)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kitty Giraudel)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alexander Dubovoy)
articles.description: Next.js has strong opinions about how to organize JavaScript but not CSS. How can we develop patterns that encourage best CSS practices while also following the framework‚Äôs logic? The answer is surprisingly simple ‚Äî to write well-structured CSS that balances global and local styling concerns.
articles.title: Global vs. Local Styling In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: Gatsby recently announced the launch of ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù. In this article, Paul Scanlon explains how to get the current location of the International Space Station (ISS) as it orbits the Earth in real-time using [Gatsby Functions](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/reference/functions/) and then display it on a 3D interactive globe using [React Three Fibre](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber).

articles.author: Clean Code Studio
articles.description:
A Linux cheat sheet for beginners (short, sweet, and to the point)
Navigation Commands:
passwd - change password
ls - list directory (Can point at any point on the machine)



-la a flag that lists all + permissions and hidden files
pwd - print working directory - check where you're at
cd - change directory (Can address at any point in the machine file system)
mkdir - make directory
rmdir - remove director
rm - remove files
echo - sends data (if no destination is given than data is sent as output to the terminal)
cp copy a file (cp [source] [desintation])
mv - mv a file (mv [source] [desintation])
locate - locate a file on the machine (locate [filename])
updatedb - updates the directory database (must run before running locate)
man - manual page of any command
grep - search for the followi‚Ä¶
articles.title: Linux Terminal Cheat Sheet (Useful for Beginners)

articles.author: Franco Cuarterolo
articles.description:
Renovando git: bye bye, checkout


Hay una serie de comandos de git que nos sabemos de memoria, pero existe uno en particular que tiene m√∫ltiples usos: git checkout.
Ah pero que tenga m√∫ltiples uso significa que es m√°s practico. Si, y m√°s probable que te equivoques
git checkout es un comando que podemos usar para crear y borrar branches, navegar entre ellas y eliminar cambios que no est√°n en estado de stage.
Ahora, la gente de git se despabil√≥ y se dio cuenta de que ser√≠a mejor tener comandos m√°s verbosos para las distintas acciones que hacemos con nuestro controlador de versiones.
Cada uno de los siguientes comandos que te voy a mostrar realizan la misma acci√≥n que hac√≠amos antes con git checkout pero escrito de una forma m√°s amigable
Cuando queremos crear una rama, es normal que nos encontremos usando el comando git checkout mi-rama. Para hacerlo m√°s entendible, lo vamos a cambiar por git branch mi-rama
Es normal cambiar a una rama de un colega para revisar sus cambios o querer volver a develop para tener los √∫ltimos cambios. Yo siempre us√© para esto git checkout rama-de-mi-colega. hasta que descubr√≠ que existe un comando que es mucho m√°s claro: git switch rama-de-mi-colega
Cuando ya separ√© cuales son los cambios que van en el commit, lo dem√°s se descarta, y para descartar recurrimos al git checkout -- .. Hoy en d√≠a git te recomienda utilizar git restore .
Utilizar el mismo comando para todo puede ser super practico, pero si reci√©n estas empezando, puede que te provoque un par de USB (USB? ABC? ACV!). Nuestros comandos y nuestros procesos deben dejar claras nuestras intenciones, de esta manera podemos compartir un paso a paso y ser lo m√°s claros posibles en nuestra comunicaci√≥n t√©cnica.
Fuentes:
git branch
git switch
git retore
articles.title: Renovando git: bye bye, checkout

This post originally appeared in my free daily newsletter on startups and engineering. 
https://matt-rickard.com/subscribe/
The key to achieving world-class expertise in any skill, is to a large extent, a matter of practicing the correct way, for a total of around 10,000 hours ‚Äî Malcolm Gladwell in Outsiders
Well, I'm certainly not a world-class expert, but I have put my 10,000 hours of deliberate practice into programming. Here are 31 of my reflections on programming.
These are reflections only about pure coding ‚Äî no lessons sum up to "programming is about people" or "how to be a senior technical leader" (arguably more important to a career, but not the topic of this post).
These reflections are just about deliberately writing code for 10,000 hours. Most don't apply to beginners. These re‚Ä¶
articles.title: Reflections on 10,000 Hours of Programming

articles.title: C# Loops - Part 3: Do..While and While Loops

articles.author: Grant
articles.description:
For Each Loops


The For Each Loop in concept works like any other loop in that it iterates over an object a number of times. However in a Foreach loop it will go from the first item all the way through to end in sequence. Unless, you manipulate the sequence by skipping items using the continue keyword. 
The foreach loop can iterate over any object that inherits from the IEnumerable class (e.g lists, collections). 
As already mentioned, it does this in order of the list, i.e order the items were loaded in / added to the list (or ordered). It does this because it iterates over the instances of the list. An instance is a concrete occurrence of any object, existing usually during runtime, from memory. 
Example:
var names = new List<string>();
names.Add("Grant", "Barry", "Jenny‚Äù,"Shaun");

for‚Ä¶
articles.title: C# Loops - Part 2 : For Each Loops

articles.author: Lucien Boix
articles.description:
If you are lucky, the disk usage was already monitored and you have been warned on time. Otherwise it's already too late and some of your apps are simply not working anymore. To help you get back on track asap, here are some useful commands I found throughout the years to quickly and safely made room again on your instance / server.
First connect to it via SSH of course and become root with sudo su -
Then given your case, if you are using on it Docker to run containers :
if your app is still running, clean Docker resources smoothly




docker images -q | xargs docker rmi
docker container prune -f
docker image prune -a -f
docker system prune -a -f

if you app is already down, clean all Docker resources in one shot




docker system prune

if a container does not rotate its log, that may rep‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to clean some disk space on a Linux instance ?

Postul√© a Laboratoria en julio de 2017. Una de mis grandes amigas me hab√≠a contado sobre la iniciativa y me pareci√≥ muy bueno para ser verdad. La carrera que estudi√© no me ofrec√≠a las posibilidades de acceder a un sueldo competitivo o a condiciones laborales justas. Laboratoria ofrec√≠a brindar las herramientas t√©cnicas y socioemocionales para incursionar al sector tecnol√≥gico, incluso sin poseer conocimientos previos sobre programaci√≥n y al mismo tiempo, reducir la brecha de g√©nero que existe en las carreras pertenecientes a STEM.
Despu√©s de un proceso de admisi√≥n largo y poco m√°s de seis meses de bootcamp (estuve en la 5ta generaci√≥n en la CDMX), egres√© y consegu√≠ mi primer empleo como software specialist.
Es cierto que desde entonces mis ingresos han aumentado, tengo una carrera de tres ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Mi experiencia en Laboratoria y la importancia de priorizar la salud mental

articles.author: Kinanee Samson
articles.description:
Objected Oriented Programming is a great software development approach on it's own however as your software becomes more complex you might even realize that OOP introduces as much problem as it solves and you can end up having poorly maintained software. The need for a suitable format for handling the complexity that arises with OOP gave rise to the SOLID application design principle. The SOLID principles are a set of software design guidelines for creating readable and maintainable code. They serve as the building blocks for building large and complex software with OOP approach. 
You should know that these principles are not some form of checklist that you should explicitly follow when writing software, however they just serve as guides that can aid you with your program design especially‚Ä¶
articles.title: Solid Design Principles

articles.author: Angelos Rinas
articles.description:
Who is Qovery?


Qovery is a platform that aims to simplify cloud hosting. For those that may not have heard, Qovery is a CaaS and aims to provide beginners an easy alternative to what is usually a complicated process, hosting applications on the cloud. Qovery tries to make cloud hosting easy, without the end user having to worry about deploying and maintaining.
But, let's dive deeper, how does it work? Well, Qovery uses the power of Kubernetes, the reliability of AWS and the simplicity of Heroku to host applications. Their engine source code is available on Github for everyone to contribute! 
 / 
        engine
      
    
Deploy your apps on any Cloud providers in just a few seconds ‚ö°


  





    


Qovery Engine is an open-source abstraction layer library that turns easy apps deployme‚Ä¶
articles.title: How Qovery simplifies Cloud Hosting

articles.author: K
articles.description:
Since I started working on my SaaS product, I've learned and worked with TypeScript for some months now. My frontend, backend, and even infrastructure code is written in TypeScript, and I quite enjoy sharing interfaces between these parts of my application with a mono repo.
TypeScript is an excellent addition to JavaScript, but some things took me some time to get into my head, one of them being union types.
This all might seem obvious for people used to static typing, but for me, it wasn't evident at first :D
One of the essential features of TypeScript is annotating your variables and functions with types that are based on JavaScript types but will be entirely invisible for JavaScript later.
Tools like ESBuild will throw away all TypeScript specific syntax and bundle up the remaining Java‚Ä¶
articles.title: A Basic TypeScript Insight for JavaScript Devs
